newsitem.title: USA: "Smart" cash cards pose law enforcement challenges.
newsitem.headline: "Smart" cash cards pose law enforcement challenges.

text.p: "Smart cards" that store electronic currency have the potential to revolutionize commerce, but the emerging technology poses challenges for the law enforcement community, government officials said Friday.
"The same electronic commerce technology that will save time and money is also capable of being abused," said Peter Toren, senior attorney in the U.S. Justice Department's computer fraud division.
The so-called stored-value cards resemble credit cards but contain a computer chip that can effectively store cash.

Toren, speaking at a conference at American University's law school here, warned that the cards offer the "threat of the perfect counterfeit" because any criminal that can copy them "can create an unending stream of money."
At the same time, private industry has attempted to address consumers' privacy concerns by developing technology that allows them to retain anonymity when using the cards.
That too will affect the ability of law enforcement officials in their ability to trace criminal activity, said Lucy Morris, assistant director for credit practices at the Federal Trade Commission.

"Everything that is good about these systems ... is bad about them" for financial law enforcement," added Stephen Kroll, financial crimes enforcement network legal counsel for the U.S. Treasury Department.

Toren noted that the practice of money laundering has become increasingly difficult for criminals but he said the new technology opens new avenues for abuse. "These systems could undo years of hard work in this area," he said.
He called for striking a balance between anonymity and accountability. "Criminals also benefit from anonymity," Toren said. "We must be able to hold individuals that harm others accountable."
